intro: Erodium chumbalense, commonly known as the Andean mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly found in the Andean regions of Peru and Bolivia. It belongs to the family Leguminosae (Fabaceae), which is characterized by its pod fruits and often nitrogen-fixing abilities. The plant typically grows in rocky or arid environments, showcasing a low-growing, mat-forming habit. Its small, heart-shaped leaves and clusters of pink or purple flowers make it a distinctive species within its habitat. Erodium chumbalense is of interest to botanists due to its ecological adaptations and potential medicinal properties.
